title: 112_hr6398
content: The "Home Energy Savings Act of 2012" may modify and extend the credit for nonbusiness energy property. The Home Energy Savings Act of 2012 proposes changes to the tax credit for nonbusiness energy property. The amendments include making the credit permanent, increasing the limit to $1,000, including labor costs in the credit, and specifying details for roofs. The Home Energy Savings Act of 2012 proposes changes to the tax credit for nonbusiness energy property, including making the credit permanent, increasing the limit to $1,000, and specifying details for roofs and residential energy property expenditures. Amendments include modifying the requirements for roofing products and qualified natural gas, propane, or oil furnaces. The term `qualified natural gas, propane, or oil furnace or hot water boiler' refers to specific efficiency rates for different types of heating systems, including annual fuel utilization efficiency requirements for natural gas, propane, and oil furnaces and boilers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include requirements for furnaces and water heaters, specifying the use of an electronically commutated blower motor for furnaces and changes in terminology for water heaters. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include requirements for water heaters, specifying energy efficiency standards for natural gas or propane storage and tankless water heaters. The maximum tax credit for qualifying water heaters is $1,000. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include energy efficiency standards for natural gas or propane water heaters. The maximum tax credit for qualifying water heaters is $1,000, with specific requirements for energy factors and thermal efficiency levels. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include energy efficiency standards for natural gas or propane water heaters. The tax credit for qualifying water heaters is up to $1,000, with specific requirements for energy factors and thermal efficiency levels. No credit will be allowed unless proper documentation is included on the tax return. Taxpayer must include the verifiable product identification number on their tax return for qualified energy efficiency improvements and residential energy property expenditures. The verifiable product identification number is defined as a specific code for insulation materials or systems. The taxpayer must provide detailed information about insulation installed, including thickness, coverage area, and R-value, either from a contractor or as required by the Secretary. The taxpayer must provide specific identification numbers for various energy-efficient products, as determined by the Secretary. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2013, with a permanent extension for property placed in service after December 31, 2011.
